explanation_of_expression: 우리 is a pronoun in Korean that is used to refer to 'we', 'our', or 'us'. It is used to indicate a group of people that includes the speaker.
image_description0: A group of objects that represent a collective, such as a stack of books or a pile of coins.
image_description1: The image shows a collection of items that belong to a group, symbolizing the concept of 'we' or 'our'.
image_description2: Imagine a scenario where multiple objects are gathered together, representing a collective or a group. This emphasizes the idea of '우리' or 'we'.
image_description3: The image depicts a group of objects or items that represent a collective, symbolizing the concept of '우리' or 'we'.
explanation_of_syllables: 우 - our (it represents the concept of a collective or a group), 리 - pronoun (it indicates the speaker and others as a group)
sentence_example: 우리는 함께 공부해요. (We study together.)

explanation_of_expression: The expression '살다' means 'to live' in English.
image_description0: A cozy house with a chimney and smoke coming out of it, representing the concept of living in a home.
image_description1: The image shows a comfortable house with a garden, symbolizing the idea of a peaceful and fulfilling life.
image_description2: Imagine a serene countryside with a beautiful house surrounded by nature, illustrating the peacefulness and tranquility of living.
image_description3: The image depicts a vibrant cityscape with tall buildings and bustling streets, representing the concept of urban living.
explanation_of_syllables: 살 - life (it represents the concept of existence or being alive), 다 - to do (it indicates an action or behavior)
sentence_example: 나는 한국에서 살고 있어요. (I am living in Korea.)

explanation_of_expression: The word '그래서' is used to indicate a cause-and-effect relationship between two events or actions. It is used to express that the second event or action is a result or consequence of the first event or action.
image_description0: A line graph showing an upward trend, indicating the cause and effect relationship represented by '그래서'.
image_description1: The image shows a domino effect, where one domino falling leads to the next one falling. This represents the cause and effect relationship expressed by '그래서'.
image_description2: In a comic strip, a character is shown planting a seed, and in the next panel, a fully grown tree is shown. This emphasizes the cause and effect relationship represented by '그래서'.
image_description3: The image shows a person holding a watering can and watering a plant. This simple image represents the cause and effect relationship expressed by '그래서'.
explanation_of_syllables: 그 - that, 그래 - like that, 그래서 - because of that
sentence_example: 오늘 비가 왔으니까 우산을 가져가세요. 그래서 비에 안 젖을 거예요. (It rained today, so please take an umbrella. Therefore, you won't get wet in the rain.)

explanation_of_expression: This expression is used to indicate an additional item or idea that is being added to a list or a statement.
image_description0: A puzzle with missing pieces, and one additional piece that perfectly fits into the puzzle.
image_description1: A set of keys with one extra key attached to it.
image_description2: A group of people standing in a line, and one person standing slightly apart from the line, emphasizing their individuality.
image_description3: A row of books on a shelf, and one book placed on top of the shelf, symbolizing an additional book that doesn't fit in the row.
explanation_of_syllables: 그리 - like that, 그 - that, 이 - and, 고 - and
sentence_example: 오늘은 공부하고, 운동하고, 그리고 친구와 만나기로 했어요. (Today, I decided to study, exercise, and meet my friend as well.)

explanation_of_expression: 하나 means 'one' in Korean.
image_description0: A single coin on a table.
image_description1: There is a single coin on a table.
image_description2: In a room with many objects, there is only one coin on a table.
image_description3: A coin representing the concept of 'one'.
image_tags: solitary, unique, lone, singular, isolated, distinct,
explanation_of_syllables: 하 - meaning 'one', 나 - meaning 'self'
sentence_example: 저는 하나의 사과를 샀어요. (I bought one apple.)

explanation_of_expression: The word '같이' means 'together' in English. It is used to indicate doing something with someone or being in the same place or situation as someone.
image_description0: A group of people walking side by side in the same direction.
image_description1: The image shows a group of people walking together in a park.
image_description2: In a beautiful park, a group of friends are walking together, enjoying each other's company.
image_description3: The image depicts a group of friends sitting around a bonfire, laughing and enjoying each other's company.
explanation_of_syllables: 같 - same, 이 - with, together
sentence_example: 우리는 항상 같이 공부해요. (We always study together.)

explanation_of_expression: 분 is a Korean word that can be translated as 'minute', 'time', or 'amount'. It refers to a specific unit of time or a portion of something.
image_description0: An hourglass with sand flowing through it, representing the passing of time.
image_description1: A clock with the minute hand pointing to a specific time, illustrating the concept of 'minute'.
image_description2: A stopwatch with the word '분' highlighted, emphasizing the measurement of time.
image_description3: An image of a calendar with a circle around a specific date, representing the concept of 'minute' as a specific point in time.
explanation_of_syllables: 분 - division (it represents the concept of dividing time or something into smaller parts)
sentence_example: 오늘은 30분 동안 운동했어요. (Today, I exercised for 30 minutes.)

explanation_of_expression: To initiate or commence an action or process.
image_description0: A clock showing the time at 12 o'clock, symbolizing the beginning of a new day.
image_description1: The image shows a sunrise, representing the start of a new day.
image_description2: A bright and vibrant image of a sun rising over a horizon, symbolizing the start of a new day filled with possibilities.
image_description3: An image of a green traffic light, indicating the start of a journey or movement.
explanation_of_syllables: 시작 - start (it represents the concept of initiating or commencing), 하 - to do (it indicates an action), 다 - to be (it indicates the completion of the action)
sentence_example: 오늘은 새로운 프로젝트를 시작했어요. (Today, I started a new project.)

additional_translations: to arise, to get out of bed
explanation_of_expression: This expression refers to the action of waking up or getting out of bed.
image_description0: A bright sun rising over the horizon, symbolizing the act of waking up and starting a new day.
image_description1: The image shows a person stretching their arms and legs after waking up, representing the action of getting up.
image_description2: In a serene setting, a person is shown opening their eyes and sitting up in bed, emphasizing the act of waking up.
image_description3: The image depicts a person lying in bed with closed eyes, and then in the next frame, the person is shown sitting up and fully awake.
image_tags: morning, sunrise, awakening, new day, beginning, energy,
explanation_of_syllables: 일 - day, 어나다 - to arise, to come into existence
sentence_example: 아침에 일어나서 먼저 물 한잔 마셔요. (In the morning, I wake up and drink a glass of water first.)

explanation_of_expression: 둘 is the Korean word for 'two'.
image_description0: An image of two identical objects side by side.
image_description1: An image that represents the concept of 'two' according to the explanation: '둘 is the Korean word for two.'
image_description2: In this image, the number '2' is highlighted and emphasized to represent the concept of 'two'.
image_description3: An image showing the number '2' in a clear and simple way.
image_tags: numeric, quantity, double, dual, pair, couple,
explanation_of_syllables: 둘 - two
sentence_example: 나는 둘의 선택 사이에서 고민하고 있다. (I am torn between two choices.)

explanation_of_expression: The word 열 means 'ten' in Korean.
image_description0: An image of a thermometer with the temperature at 10 degrees Celsius.
image_description1: The image shows a dial on a stove set to the number 10, indicating the heat level.
image_description2: In a kitchen, there is a pot on a stove with the heat set to the maximum level, which is represented by the number 10.
image_description3: An image of a number 10 written in big bold font with a background of flames.
explanation_of_syllables: 연 - ten (it represents the concept of the number ten)
sentence_example: 오늘은 열 시에 만나요. (Let's meet at ten o'clock today.)

additional_translations: to come to an end, to be finished
explanation_of_expression: 끝나다 means to reach the end or to complete something.
image_description0: A road that leads to a dead end, symbolizing the concept of reaching the end or finishing something.
image_description1: An arrow pointing towards the end of a timeline, representing the idea of reaching the end or finishing something.
image_description2: A progress bar that is filled completely, indicating the completion or end of a task.
image_description3: An hourglass with all the sand at the bottom, signifying that time has run out or something has come to an end.
image_tags: completion, conclusion, finality, termination, fulfillment, accomplishment,
explanation_of_syllables: 끝 - end, finish, 나다 - to come out, to appear
sentence_example: 오늘은 일이 끝나면 친구들과 함께 저녁을 먹으러 갈 거예요. (After work ends today, I will go out to dinner with friends.)

explanation_of_expression: The word '가족' refers to a group of people who are related to each other by blood or marriage and live together as a unit.
image_description0: A cozy living room with a dining table set for a family meal, symbolizing togetherness and unity.
image_description1: The image shows a warm and loving atmosphere in a home, with family members gathered around a table, enjoying a meal together.
image_description2: In a comfortable and harmonious home environment, family members are engaged in various activities that strengthen their bond and create lasting memories.
image_description3: The image depicts a happy family spending quality time together, engaging in activities such as playing board games, cooking, and sharing laughter.
explanation_of_syllables: 가 - house, 족 - tribe or clan
sentence_example: 우리 가족은 매주 일요일에 함께 저녁을 먹는다. (Our family eats dinner together every Sunday.)

explanation_of_expression: 다섯 is the Korean word for 'five'.
image_description0: An image of five fingers extended, representing the number five.
image_description1: The image shows a hand with all five fingers extended, representing the number five.
image_description2: In this image, the number five is emphasized with bold and large font, standing out from the rest of the text.
image_description3: The image shows the numeral '5' written in a clear and visible manner.
image_tags: numeric, counting, quantity, hand gesture, mathematics, arithmetic,
explanation_of_syllables: 다 - represents the concept of 'five', 섯 - refers to the specific number 'five'
sentence_example: 다섯 마리의 고양이가 집 앞에 있어요. (There are five cats in front of the house.)

additional_translations: to be tardy, to be delayed
explanation_of_expression: This expression is used to describe the state of being late or delayed.
image_description0: An alarm clock showing a time that is past the desired time.
image_description1: The concept of being late represented by a clock with its hands pointing to a time that has already passed.
image_description2: In a busy train station, a person is seen running towards a departing train, symbolizing the urgency of being late.
image_description3: A clock with its hands pointing to a time that is later than the expected time.
explanation_of_syllables: 늦 - late (it represents the concept of being delayed or not on time)
sentence_example: 오늘은 학교에 늦어서 선생님께 사과했어요. (Today, I apologized to the teacher for being late to school.)

explanation_of_expression: 일곱 means 'seven' in Korean.
image_description0: An image of seven colorful balloons floating in the sky.
image_description1: The image shows a set of seven colorful balloons representing the number 'seven'.
image_description2: In this image, the number '7' is highlighted and emphasized, symbolizing the meaning of '일곱'.
image_description3: The image depicts a numerical representation of '7' to represent the meaning of '일곱'.
explanation_of_syllables: 일 - one (it represents the concept of a single unit), 곱 - multiplied (it refers to the action of multiplying or increasing)
sentence_example: 오늘은 일곱 시에 만나요. (Let's meet at seven o'clock today.)

explanation_of_expression: The word 여섯 means 'six' in Korean.
image_description0: An image of six objects arranged in a line.
image_description1: The image shows a group of six items.
image_description2: In this image, the emphasis is on the concept of the number six.
image_description3: The image represents the number six with six visible objects.
image_tags: numeric, quantity, counting, numbers, math, arithmetic,
explanation_of_syllables: 여 - female (it represents the concept of femininity), 섯 - six (it refers to the number six)
sentence_example: 오늘은 여섯 시에 만나요. (Let's meet at six o'clock today.)

explanation_of_expression: 수업 is a Korean word that refers to a class or lesson.
image_description0: A classroom with desks and chairs arranged neatly, a whiteboard at the front, and textbooks on the desks.
image_description1: A classroom setting with students sitting at desks, a teacher standing at the front, and a whiteboard with notes and diagrams.
image_description2: In a classroom, a teacher is explaining a concept to students using a whiteboard and visual aids.
image_description3: An image of a classroom with students actively participating in a lesson, taking notes, and engaging in discussions.
image_tags: education, learning, school, studying, knowledge, academic,
explanation_of_syllables: 수 - water (it represents the concept of something flowing or progressing), 업 - business (it refers to a specific type of work or activity)
sentence_example: 오늘은 수업이 쉬웠어요. (Today's class was easy.)

explanation_of_expression: The expression '닦다' means to clean or wipe something by using a cloth, sponge, or other cleaning tools.
image_description0: An image of a dirty table being wiped clean with a cloth.
image_description1: An image of a surface being cleaned with a sponge.
image_description2: In this image, a person is vigorously wiping a surface clean using a cloth.
image_description3: An image showing a cloth being used to wipe a dirty surface clean.
explanation_of_syllables: 닦 - to clean or wipe, 다 - verb ending
sentence_example: 저는 매일 아침에 이불을 닦아요. (I clean the blanket every morning.)

explanation_of_expression: The word 아홉 means 'nine' in Korean.
image_description0: A clock showing the number 9.
image_description1: The number 9 written in big bold font.
image_description2: A visual representation of the number 9 with emphasis on its significance.
image_description3: An image of 9 objects arranged in a line.
image_tags: numeric, counting, quantity, mathematics, sequence, order,
explanation_of_syllables: 아 - a sound representing the number 9, 홑 - a sound representing the concept of being single or alone
sentence_example: 오늘은 아홉 시에 만나요. (Let's meet at nine o'clock today.)

explanation_of_expression: The word 셋 means 'three' in Korean.
image_description0: An image of three objects arranged in a row, representing the number three.
image_description1: The image shows three identical objects placed next to each other, symbolizing the concept of 'three'.
image_description2: In this image, the number '3' is highlighted and emphasized, representing the meaning of the word 셋.
image_description3: An image depicting the number '3' in a visually appealing way.
explanation_of_syllables: 셋 - three
sentence_example: 오늘은 셋 친구들과 함께 영화를 보았어요. (Today, I watched a movie with three friends.)

explanation_of_expression: 약속 is a noun that refers to an agreement or arrangement made between two or more people to meet or do something at a specific time and place.
image_description0: A calendar with a marked date and time for the appointment.
image_description1: A calendar with a circled date and time, indicating an appointment.
image_description2: A calendar with a highlighted date and time, emphasizing the importance of the appointment.
image_description3: A clock showing the time of the appointment.
image_tags: time-sensitive, schedule, commitment, meeting, arrangement, commitment,
explanation_of_syllables: 약 - medicine (it represents the concept of something being agreed upon or prescribed), 속 - inside (it refers to the agreement or arrangement being made within a specific timeframe)
sentence_example: 내일 저녁에 약속이 있어요. (I have an appointment tomorrow evening.)

explanation_of_expression: The word '뉴스' refers to information or reports about recent events or developments, especially those broadcasted or published by the media.
image_description0: A newspaper with the headline '뉴스' on it, indicating the presence of news articles inside.
image_description1: An image of a television screen showing the word '뉴스' with news headlines scrolling across the screen.
image_description2: In a busy newsroom, journalists are typing on their computers, surrounded by multiple screens displaying news articles with the word '뉴스' highlighted.
image_description3: A smartphone screen displaying a news app with the word '뉴스' and news articles visible.
image_tags: Informative, Current, Media, Journalism, Reporting, Updates,
explanation_of_syllables: 뉴 - new (it represents something recent or up-to-date), 스 -s (it indicates the plural form or the concept of multiple news pieces)
sentence_example: 오늘 뉴스에서 중요한 소식을 들었어요. (Today, I heard important news from the news.)

explanation_of_expression: The act of going on a trip or journey to a different place.
image_description0: A suitcase filled with clothes and a map of the world, symbolizing the idea of going on a trip.
image_description1: A map with a dotted line representing a journey from one place to another.
image_description2: A group of suitcases stacked together, emphasizing the idea of going on a trip.
image_description3: An image of a scenic landscape with mountains and a winding road, representing the experience of traveling.
image_tags: adventurous, exploration, destination, transportation, discovery, itinerary,
explanation_of_syllables: 여 - going (it represents the concept of going or moving), 행 - action (it refers to an act or action),
sentence_example: 여행을 계획하고 있어요. (I am planning a trip.)

additional_translations: early in the morning, ahead of time, prematurely
explanation_of_expression: The word '일찍' means to do something before the expected or usual time.
image_description0: A clock showing an early time in the morning, indicating the concept of doing something before the usual time.
image_description1: An alarm clock set to a time earlier than usual, symbolizing the idea of doing something ahead of time.
image_description2: A sunrise happening earlier than expected, emphasizing the concept of doing something before the usual time.
image_description3: An image of a person waking up and starting their day before sunrise, representing the idea of doing something early.
explanation_of_syllables: 일 - day, 찍 - to mark or hit, representing the action of marking or hitting the day early
sentence_example: 오늘은 일찍 일어났어요. (Today, I woke up early.)

explanation_of_expression: The word '여덟' means 'eight' in Korean.
image_description0: An image of eight objects arranged in a line.
image_description1: The image shows a group of objects, each representing the number eight.
image_description2: In this image, the number eight is highlighted and emphasized.
image_description3: The image depicts the number eight in a clear and simple way.
image_tags: numeric, counting, quantity, mathematics, numbers, sequence,
explanation_of_syllables: 여 - eight (it represents the concept of the number eight), 더 - more (it emphasizes the quantity or amount),
sentence_example: 저는 여덟 시에 일어나요. (I wake up at eight o'clock.)

additional_translations: Create additional English translations that have the same meaning as 'twenty' but are different from 스물.
explanation_of_expression: 스물 means 'twenty' in Korean.
image_description0: An image of a calendar with the number 20 circled, representing the concept of 'twenty'.
image_description1: An image of a clock showing the time as 8:20, representing the concept of 'twenty'.
image_description2: Imagine a scenario where someone is counting a stack of 20 dollar bills, emphasizing the value of 'twenty'.
image_description3: An image of a scoreboard in a sports game with the number 20 displayed, representing the concept of 'twenty'.
explanation_of_syllables: 스 - represents the sound 'seu' in Korean, 물 - represents the sound 'mul' in Korean
sentence_example: 오늘은 스물 살이 되었어요. (Today, I turned twenty years old.)

explanation_of_expression: 게임 is the Korean word for 'game'.
image_description0: An image of a game controller on a table.
image_description1: An image of a game controller, representing the concept of 'game'.
image_description2: In this image, a game controller is highlighted, emphasizing the concept of 'game'.
image_description3: An image of a game controller, symbolizing the idea of 'game'.
image_tags: entertainment, leisure, technology, electronic, fun, interactive,
explanation_of_syllables: 게 - game (it represents the concept of a recreational activity), 임 - sound (it refers to the audible aspect of the game)
sentence_example: 오늘은 친구들과 게임을 했어요. (Today, I played games with my friends.)

explanation_of_expression: The expression '서른' means the number thirty in Korean.
image_description0: An image of three sets of ten objects, representing the number thirty.
image_description1: The image shows a group of thirty objects arranged in a neat pattern.
image_description2: In this image, the number thirty is highlighted and emphasized, drawing attention to its significance.
image_description3: The image depicts the number thirty in a clear and visually appealing way.
image_tags: numeric, quantity, counting, numbers, mathematics, multiples,
explanation_of_syllables: 서 - three (referring to the number three), 른 - ten (referring to the number ten)
sentence_example: 오늘은 제 서른 번째 생일이에요. (Today is my thirtieth birthday.)

additional_translations: to feel exhausted, to feel weary
explanation_of_expression: This expression is used to describe the state of being tired or fatigued.
image_description0: A person lying in bed with closed eyes, indicating tiredness.
image_description1: The image shows a person yawning, indicating tiredness.
image_description2: In a dimly lit room, a person is sitting on a chair with their head resting on their hand, looking exhausted.
image_description3: The image depicts a person sitting at a desk with their head down, appearing tired and fatigued.
image_tags: exhaustion, fatigue, sleepiness, rest, relaxation, energy,
explanation_of_syllables: 피곤 - tired (it represents the feeling of physical or mental exhaustion), 하다 - to be
sentence_example: 오늘은 일이 많아서 피곤해요. (Today, I am tired because I have a lot of work.)

explanation_of_expression: 맥주 is the Korean word for beer.
image_description0: An image of a cold glass of beer with condensation on the outside.
image_description1: A refreshing glass of beer, perfect for a hot summer day.
image_description2: Imagine a tall glass of golden beer, with bubbles rising to the top.
image_description3: A glass of beer with a frothy head, ready to be enjoyed.
explanation_of_syllables: 맥 - wheat (referring to the main ingredient of beer), 주 - liquor (referring to the alcoholic nature of beer)
sentence_example: 오늘은 친구들과 맥주를 마시면서 즐거운 시간을 보냈어요. (Today, I had a great time with friends while drinking beer.)

explanation_of_expression: A festive event or gathering that is usually held to commemorate a special occasion or to honor a specific cultural or religious tradition.
image_description0: A colorful display of lights and decorations, symbolizing the vibrant and joyful atmosphere of a festival.
image_description1: The image depicts a lively scene with various stalls and booths, showcasing different cultural activities and traditional foods, representing the essence of a festival.
image_description2: Imagine a bustling marketplace filled with vibrant colors, lively music, and mouth-watering aromas, all coming together to create a festive atmosphere that captures the spirit of a celebration.
image_description3: The image shows a group of people gathered in an open space, enjoying music, dance, and food, creating a festive ambiance.
explanation_of_syllables: 축 - congratulations (it represents the act of expressing joy and happiness), 제 - event (it refers to a planned gathering or occasion)
sentence_example: 오늘은 축제에 가서 다양한 문화 활동을 즐겼어요. (Today, I went to the festival and enjoyed various cultural activities.)

explanation_of_expression: The word '넷' means 'four' in Korean.
image_description0: An image of four objects arranged in a line.
image_description1: The image shows four items grouped together.
image_description2: In this image, the emphasis is on the concept of 'four'.
image_description3: The image depicts the number '4' in a visually appealing way.
image_tags: numeric, counting, quantity, mathematics, arithmetic, digits,
explanation_of_syllables: 넷 - four
sentence_example: 저는 넷이 필요해요. (I need four.)

explanation_of_expression: A book or document in which you write down your personal experiences, thoughts, and feelings on a regular basis.
image_description0: An open book with a pen next to it, ready to be written in.
image_description1: A blank book with a pen on top, symbolizing the act of writing personal experiences and thoughts.
image_description2: A person sitting at a desk, writing in a book with a focused expression.
image_description3: A book with a lock on it, representing the privacy and personal nature of a diary.
explanation_of_syllables: 일 - day, 기 - record
sentence_example: 오늘은 일기를 써서 하루 동안 있었던 일들을 기록했어요. (Today, I wrote a diary and recorded the things that happened throughout the day.)

explanation_of_expression: Basketball is a team sport played on a court, where players try to score points by shooting a ball through a hoop.
image_description0: An orange ball going through a hoop.
image_description1: An orange ball going through a hoop.
image_description2: A group of players running on a basketball court, trying to shoot the ball through the hoop.
image_description3: A basketball going through a hoop.
explanation_of_syllables: 농 - farming (it represents the concept of a field or open space), 구 - ball (it refers to a round object used in various sports)
sentence_example: 오늘은 친구들과 농구를 하러 갈 거예요. (Today, I'm going to play basketball with my friends.)

explanation_of_expression: The word '늦게' means 'late' in English.
image_description0: A clock showing a time that is past the expected or desired time.
image_description1: The concept of being behind schedule or not arriving on time.
image_description2: Imagine a clock with its hands pointing to a time that is later than expected or desired.
image_description3: An image of a clock showing a time that is after the scheduled or expected time.
explanation_of_syllables: 늦 - late (it represents the concept of something happening or being done after the expected or desired time), 게 - adverbial suffix (it is used to modify the verb 'to be late')
sentence_example: 저는 항상 늦게 일어나서 학교에 늦게 도착해요. (I always wake up late and arrive at school late.)

explanation_of_expression: A 도우미 is someone who provides help or support to others.
image_description0: A picture of a toolbox with various tools inside, symbolizing the idea of a 도우미 being a helpful resource.
image_description1: The image shows a set of keys hanging on a hook, representing a 도우미 who has access to different resources and can assist others.
image_description2: In a busy office, a 도우미 is depicted as a computer program that organizes files and schedules, making work more efficient.
image_description3: The image shows a pair of hands holding a puzzle piece, symbolizing a 도우미 who helps put things together and solve problems.
image_tags: helpful, support, resourceful, efficient, problem-solving, assistance,
explanation_of_syllables: 도 - way (it represents the concept of providing a path or method), 우 - help (it refers to the act of assisting or supporting), 미 - beauty (it symbolizes the positive impact and outcome of the help provided)
sentence_example: 도우미가 제공하는 정보는 매우 유용합니다. (The information provided by the helper is very useful.)

explanation_of_expression: The word 마흔 represents the number forty in Korean.
image_description0: An image of a clock showing the time as 40 minutes past the hour.
image_description1: The image shows a set of four tens blocks, representing the number forty.
image_description2: In this image, the number 40 is highlighted and emphasized.
image_description3: The image depicts the number 40 written in large, bold font.
image_tags: numbers, quantity, counting, math, digits, arithmetic,
explanation_of_syllables: 마 - horse (it represents the concept of a horse), 흔 - old (it refers to something that has reached the age of forty)
sentence_example: 오늘은 제 마흔 번째 생일이에요. (Today is my fortieth birthday.)

explanation_of_expression: To shave
image_description0: An image of a razor and shaving cream on a bathroom counter
image_description1: The act of shaving with a razor and shaving cream
image_description2: A close-up image of a razor gliding over a lathered face
image_description3: An image of a razor and shaving cream with a hand holding the razor
explanation_of_syllables: 면 - surface, 도 - to cut
sentence_example: 오늘 아침에 면도를 했어요. (I shaved this morning.)

explanation_of_expression: This expression is used to ask for the time.
image_description0: A clock with no hands, indicating the concept of asking for the time.
image_description1: An image of a clock with question marks instead of numbers, representing the idea of asking for the time.
image_description2: In a dark room, a spotlight shines on a clock, emphasizing the act of asking for the time.
image_description3: An image of a person pointing at a clock, symbolizing the act of asking for the time.
explanation_of_syllables: 몇 - how many (it represents the concept of asking for a quantity), 시 - hour (it refers to a specific unit of time)
sentence_example: 오늘은 몇 시에 만나요? (What time are we meeting today?)

explanation_of_expression: This word is used to describe something that is usual or normal, or to indicate a general situation or behavior.
image_description0: A clock showing the time 12:00, representing the usual time for lunch.
image_description1: The image shows a clock with the time set at 12:00, indicating the usual time for lunch.
image_description2: In a simple image, a clock is shown with the time set at 12:00, emphasizing the usual time for lunch.
image_description3: The image shows a clock with the time set at 12:00, representing the usual time for lunch.
explanation_of_syllables: 보통 - usual, normal
sentence_example: 보통 저는 아침에 커피를 마셔요. (Usually, I drink coffee in the morning.)

explanation_of_expression: This expression refers to the action of doing the laundry, which involves washing and cleaning clothes.
image_description0: A pile of dirty clothes waiting to be washed.
image_description1: A stack of clothes being washed in a washing machine.
image_description2: A laundry room with a washing machine and clothes hanging to dry.
image_description3: An image showing a person washing clothes in a basin.
explanation_of_syllables: 빨 - to wash, 래 - clothes
sentence_example: 오늘은 빨래를 하기로 했어요. (Today, I decided to do the laundry.)

explanation_of_expression: The expression 샤워(를) 하다 means 'to take a shower'.
image_description0: A bathroom with a showerhead and water flowing from it.
image_description1: A bathroom with a showerhead and water flowing from it, representing the act of taking a shower.
image_description2: In a bathroom, water is flowing from a showerhead, symbolizing the act of taking a shower.
image_description3: An image of a showerhead with water flowing from it, representing the act of taking a shower.
explanation_of_syllables: 샤 - shower, 워 - to, 하다 - do
sentence_example: 오늘은 피곤해서 샤워를 하지 않았어요. (Today, I didn't take a shower because I was tired.)

explanation_of_expression: To wash one's face
image_description0: An image of a bathroom sink with running water and a bar of soap
image_description1: The act of washing one's face with water and soap
image_description2: In this image, a person is standing in front of a bathroom sink, splashing water on their face to wash it
image_description3: An image showing a person standing in front of a bathroom sink, washing their face with water and soap
explanation_of_syllables: 세 - wash, 수 - face
sentence_example: 매일 아침에 세수를 해요. (I wash my face every morning.)

explanation_of_expression: 쉰 is a Korean word that means fifty. It is used to represent the number 50 in Korean.
image_description0: An image of a clock with the time set to 50 minutes.
image_description1: An image of a speedometer with the needle pointing to 50.
image_description2: Imagine a car racing on a track with the number 50 painted on its side.
image_description3: An image of a scoreboard showing the number 50.
explanation_of_syllables: 쉰 - fifty
sentence_example: 오늘은 제 친구의 생일이에요. 그래서 쉰 개의 선물을 준비했어요. (Today is my friend's birthday. So, I prepared fifty gifts.)

explanation_of_expression: 아이 means 'child' in English.
image_description0: A small toy car on a colorful play mat.
image_description1: The image shows a small toy car on a colorful play mat, representing a child's playtime.
image_description2: In this image, a small toy car is placed on a colorful play mat, emphasizing the concept of a child's playtime.
image_description3: The image depicts a small toy car on a colorful play mat, symbolizing a child's playtime.
explanation_of_syllables: 아 - child (it represents the concept of a young individual), 이 - person (it refers to a human being)
sentence_example: 저는 아이를 돌봅니다. (I take care of children.)

explanation_of_expression: This expression means to have breakfast.
image_description0: A plate with a variety of breakfast foods, such as toast, eggs, and bacon.
image_description1: A plate of food with toast, eggs, and bacon, representing a typical breakfast.
image_description2: A delicious breakfast spread with toast, eggs, and bacon, perfect for starting the day.
image_description3: An image of a plate with toast, eggs, and bacon, symbolizing a breakfast meal.
explanation_of_syllables: 아침 - morning, 을 - object particle, 먹 - to eat, 다 - verb ending
sentence_example: 오늘은 아침을 먹지 않았어요. (Today, I didn't have breakfast.)

explanation_of_expression: The word 아흔 represents the number ninety in Korean.
image_description0: An image of a clock showing the time as 9:00, representing the number ninety.
image_description1: The image shows a set of ninety objects arranged in a line, representing the number ninety.
image_description2: Imagine a scenario where there are ninety identical items placed in a row, emphasizing the concept of the number ninety.
image_description3: An image of a number 90 written in a bold and clear font, representing the number ninety.
image_tags: numerical, quantity, counting, math, numbers, sequence,
explanation_of_syllables: 아 - a (it represents the sound 'a'), 흔 - heun (it represents the sound 'heun')
sentence_example: 나는 아흔 책을 읽었다. (I read ninety books.)

explanation_of_expression: The expression 여든 means 'eighty' in Korean.
image_description0: An image of a clock showing the time 80 minutes past the hour.
image_description1: The expression 여든 can be represented by an image of a long road with 80 mile markers.
image_description2: Imagine a scenario where there are 80 identical objects arranged in a line, representing the concept of 여든.
image_description3: An image of a large number 80, symbolizing the expression 여든.
image_tags: numbers, quantity, counting, math, measurement, time,
explanation_of_syllables: 여 - eight (refers to the number 8), 든 - ten (refers to the number 10)
sentence_example: 오늘은 여든 살이 되었어요. (Today, I turned eighty years old.)

additional_translations: to go on a trip, to take a trip
explanation_of_expression: This expression means to engage in the activity of traveling.
image_description0: A suitcase filled with clothes and a map laid out on a table, representing the preparation and planning involved in traveling.
image_description1: The image shows a passport with various stamps from different countries, symbolizing the experience of traveling to different places.
image_description2: Imagine a scenic landscape with mountains, rivers, and a winding road, emphasizing the idea of exploring new places through travel.
image_description3: The image depicts a person standing at an airport with a suitcase, ready to embark on a journey.
image_tags: adventurous, exploration, discovery, wanderlust, itinerary, destination,
explanation_of_syllables: 여행(을) 하다 - 여행 means 'travel' and 하다 means 'to do'.
sentence_example: 여름에 해외로 여행을 가고 싶어요. (I want to travel abroad in the summer.)

explanation_of_expression: The word '예순' means 'sixty' in Korean.
image_description0: An image of a clock showing the time as 60 minutes past the hour.
image_description1: The image shows a number 60 written on a piece of paper.
image_description2: In this image, the number 60 is highlighted and emphasized.
image_description3: The image depicts a group of 60 objects arranged in a pattern.
image_tags: numbers, quantity, counting, math, time, clock,
explanation_of_syllables: 예 - sixty (it represents the concept of the number 60), 순 - order (it refers to a specific position in a sequence)
sentence_example: 오늘은 예순 살이 되었어요. (Today, I turned sixty years old.)

explanation_of_expression: The word '이' refers to the teeth in Korean.
image_description0: An image of a toothbrush and toothpaste.
image_description1: An image of a set of teeth.
image_description2: In this image, the focus is on a tooth.
image_description3: An image of a dental clinic with dental tools.
image_tags: dental, oral, hygiene, health, dentist, toothpaste,
explanation_of_syllables: 이 - tooth
sentence_example: 이를 깨물다 (to bite)

explanation_of_expression: This expression means to brush one's teeth.
image_description0: An image of a toothbrush and toothpaste on a bathroom sink.
image_description1: The image shows a toothbrush and toothpaste, representing the act of brushing one's teeth.
image_description2: In this image, the focus is on the toothbrush and toothpaste, emphasizing the action of brushing one's teeth.
image_description3: An image depicting a toothbrush and toothpaste, symbolizing the act of brushing one's teeth.
explanation_of_syllables: 이를 - teeth, 닦다 - to brush
sentence_example: 저는 매일 아침에 이를 닦아요. (I brush my teeth every morning.)

additional_translations: to have a conversation, to have a chat
explanation_of_expression: This expression means to engage in a conversation or to talk with someone.
image_description0: A group of people sitting in a circle, engaged in a lively conversation.
image_description1: The image shows two people sitting across from each other, engaged in a conversation.
image_description2: In a busy cafe, two friends are sitting at a table, engrossed in a conversation.
image_description3: The image depicts two people talking to each other, with speech bubbles showing their conversation.
explanation_of_syllables: 이야 - story, 기 - to do (verb ending)
sentence_example: 저는 친구와 이야기를 하고 싶어요. (I want to talk with my friend.)

additional_translations: to keep a diary, to write in a journal
explanation_of_expression: This expression refers to the act of writing down personal thoughts, experiences, or events in a diary.
image_description0: A small notebook with a pen next to it, symbolizing the act of writing a diary.
image_description1: A diary with a pen on top, representing the act of writing personal thoughts and experiences.
image_description2: In a cozy room, a person is sitting at a desk with a diary open in front of them, writing down their thoughts and experiences.
image_description3: An open diary with a pen next to it, indicating the act of writing personal thoughts and experiences.
explanation_of_syllables: 일 - day (refers to a specific period of time), 기 - record (represents the act of writing down)
sentence_example: 오늘은 일기를 써서 하루 동안 있었던 일들을 기록했어요. (Today, I wrote a diary and recorded the things that happened throughout the day.)

explanation_of_expression: The expression '일흔' means 'seventy' in Korean.
image_description0: An image of a calendar with the number '70' circled.
image_description1: The image shows a calendar with the number '70' highlighted, representing the expression '일흔'.
image_description2: In this image, the number '70' is emphasized to represent the expression '일흔'.
image_description3: An image of a calendar with the number '70' circled, representing the expression '일흔'.
explanation_of_syllables: 일 - one, 흔 - ten (it represents the concept of the number ten)
sentence_example: 오늘은 제 할머니의 일흔 번째 생일이에요. (Today is my grandmother's seventieth birthday.)

explanation_of_expression: This expression means to have dinner or to eat dinner.
image_description0: A table with a plate of food and utensils set for dinner.
image_description1: The image shows a mealtime scene with a plate of food and utensils, representing having dinner.
image_description2: In this image, there is a table set for dinner with a plate of food and utensils, emphasizing the act of having dinner.
image_description3: The image depicts a person sitting at a table, eating a meal in the evening, representing having dinner.
explanation_of_syllables: 저녁 - evening, mealtime, 을 - object particle, 먹 - to eat, 다 - verb ending
sentence_example: 오늘은 친구들과 함께 저녁을 먹었어요. (Today, I had dinner with my friends.)

explanation_of_expression: This expression is used to indicate a small quantity or degree of something.
image_description0: A plate with a small portion of food on it.
image_description1: A plate with a small portion of food on it.
image_description2: In a picture, a plate with a small portion of food is highlighted to emphasize the concept of a small quantity.
image_description3: A plate with a small portion of food on it.
explanation_of_syllables: 조 - small, 금 - amount
sentence_example: 저는 조금 피곤해요. (I am a little tired.)

explanation_of_expression: The word 쯤 is used to indicate an approximate or rough amount or time.
image_description0: A clock with the hands pointing to different numbers, indicating an approximate time.
image_description1: A ruler with markings that are not precise, indicating an approximate measurement.
image_description2: A signpost with arrows pointing in different directions, indicating an approximate location.
image_description3: A group of scattered objects with varying sizes, indicating an approximate amount.
explanation_of_syllables: 쯤 - around, about
sentence_example: 오늘 쯤에 도착할 거예요. (I will arrive around today.)

additional_translations: to be friendly, to be nice
explanation_of_expression: 친절하다 means to be kind or friendly towards others.
image_description0: A smiling sun shining brightly on a field of blooming flowers.
image_description1: The image shows a sunny day with colorful flowers blooming in a field, representing the kindness and warmth of 친절하다.
image_description2: Imagine a beautiful sunny day with a field full of colorful flowers, symbolizing the kindness and friendliness of 친절하다.
image_description3: The image depicts a bright and sunny day with a field of blooming flowers, representing the kindness and warmth of 친절하다.
explanation_of_syllables: 친 - close, intimate; 절 - polite, courteous; 하다 - to do
sentence_example: 그는 항상 친절하게 다른 사람들을 대해요. (He always treats others kindly.)

additional_translations: to apply makeup, to do makeup
explanation_of_expression: This expression refers to the action of applying cosmetics to enhance one's appearance.
image_description0: A table with various makeup products such as foundation, lipstick, and eyeshadow.
image_description1: The image shows a collection of makeup products including foundation, lipstick, and eyeshadow.
image_description2: In this image, the focus is on the process of applying makeup to enhance one's appearance.
image_description3: The image depicts a hand holding a makeup brush and applying makeup on a face.
explanation_of_syllables: 화장 - makeup (it represents the action of enhancing one's appearance)
sentence_example: 오늘은 친구와 약속이 있어서 화장을 했어요. (Today, I put on makeup because I had plans with my friend.)
